history.content:
As painful as 70 was, I would recommend 170. It's kind of an unofficial "core" class, and will be especially useful if you want to work on backend. If you liked 61C, 152 and 162 are the upper-div classes that cover the 61C material in more depth. If you liked 188 and DS100, maybe try 189 (or 126/127, if you aren't feeling ready to handle 189 just yet).

-----------------

Definitely echoing to take 170, as almost every job/internship interview will involve questions regarding algorithms. 161 is definitely a good class to take even if you aren't interested in going into security, as it shows you many ways in which careless coding practices can make your code vulnerable to attacks, which is useful to know going into industry. Additionally, I felt that 186, although dry and boring at some points, really helped me appreciate databases, which are essential to backend engineering.

As painful as 70 was, I would recommend 170. It's kind of an unofficial "core" class, and will be especially useful if you want to work on backend. If you liked 61C, 152 and 162 are the upper-div classes that cover the 61C material in more depth. If you liked 188 and DS100, maybe try 189 (or 126/127, if you aren't feeling ready to handle 189 just yet).

children.subject: Thank you for the response. How about CS161? I'm registered with cs161 and cs170 for now.
More balanced load, and technically 162 you would benefit from having partners prior to the class starting, so this seems like a more feasible choice.

Taking 162 and 170 together? Bad idea. At least it was a bad choice for me. And as the above anon said, having a reliable pre-arranged team is really important. Once you get stuck with some random people you don't know and they turn out to be bad teammates, there's no way out and your semester will be miserable.

Thank you for the response again! :)

What if I take 161, 186, 170 all at once, is it doable?

I took stat133, cs61b, ds100, cs188 all at once, and the workload was not too bad except dead & final week was hell :(

No prob :) Taking 3 techs will always have bad days and weeks, but if you are diligent every day, you'll make it without terrible stress.

170 problem sets every week. Only 4-5 problems, basically just write an algorithm. Although the hw is simple and "short", these problems are very difficult to think of the answer, so it takes a while to complete. study groups and office hours are crucial.

186 and 161 are not easy at all, but you won't be piled with hw daily, and the material isn't super difficult. 186 projects are a bit long and difficult though, so expect some weeks to be very difficult.

I'd say go for it, but taking days off, extra curricular activities, and socializing will definitely take a hit. If you focus on learning and not getting A+, that should alleviate stress during overwhelming day.
Take 170 and 162, and basically nothing else(take fillers or easy breadth). Focus hard and you'll feel great after next semester ends and ready to tackle 186 in the spring and ML courses.
I hated 70, but enjoyed 170. That that as you will. I do think 170 should be a class everyone takes.

history.content:
Hi all,

I don't know what to take for this Fall and next Spring semester.

Can anyone recommend 'must take' CS courses?

Here is the list of courses that I've taken:

- CS61A, CS61B, CS61C (really enjoyed all of them)

- CS70 (was full of pain)

- CS188 (was enjoyable but the exam was hard.)

- DS100 (was enjoyable)

fyi. I want to be a backend engineer in the future :)

Thank you in advance!
history.subject: don't know what courses to take.
